OSI Model

Networking basics | OSI Model Stack

Posted by Aravind on 4:25 AM, June 16, 2021

The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection)

  1. APPLICATION LAYER
  2. PRESENTATION LAYER
  3. SESSION LAYER
  4. TRANSPORT LAYER
  5. NETWORK LAYER
  6. DATA LINK LAYER
  7. PHYSICAL LAYER

7. APPLICATION LAYER

This layer basically provides an interface for the application to transmit the data. The data is being passed to the presentation layer.

6. PRESENTATION LAYER

The presentation layer translates the data into a standardised format and all the encryption, compression and other forms of transformations to the data takes place in this layer. Once the transformations are completed the data is being passed over to session layer.

5. SESSION LAYER

The session layer manages the connection being made with the remote application. This layer checks if a connect can be made with the remote application. If the connection cannot be made it sends back an error. If the session can be created the session layer creates the session and maintains it. It also makes sure the connection is unique. When the session is created the data is passed down to the transport layer.

4. TRANSPORT LAYER

The main function of transport layer is to choose over which protocol the data is to be transmitted. The two common protocols would be TCP (TRANSMISSION CONTROL PROTOCOL) and UDP (USER DATAGRAM PROTOCOL). TCP is a connection-based protocol, a connection is made between two computers in order to send the data packets to the other.A TCP connection ensures to remains in contant communication until the duration of the request and any lost data is re-sent. Now coming to UDP, it is the exact opposite of TCP. UDP throws the data packets to the receiving computer without any confirmation or connection. There is no connection being made from the local to remote computer. If the data is lost, the data will not be re-sent. The UDP is mostly used for speed, for example in video streaming. The TCP is choosed when accuracy is important, for example in file transfers. With a protocol selected the data packets are divided into bite-sized pieces. In UDP it is called as DATAGRAM and in TCP it is SEGMENTS.

3. NETWORK LAYER

Network layer is used to determines the best route for the data packet to travel. For instance if a website is being entered in the browser the network layer gets IP address of the site and decides the best route to take. This is where logical addressing comes in. A logical address lets you access a network device by using an address that you assign. Currently most commong addressing is IPV4 format.

2. DATA LINK

The data link layer is focused on physical addressing of the transmission. It receives packets from network layer which contains the IP of the endpoint, the data link layer adds in the MAC address of the endpoint computer. The data link layer also makes sure the data isn't been corrupted during the transmission.

1. PHYSICAL LAYER

The physical layer consists of the hardware components. This is where the electrical pulses that make up data transfer over a network are sent and received. It converts the binary data of transmission into signals and transmits over to the remote computer and also receives the incoming signals and converting them into binary data.
